messages.msgSnippet: Don t forget Jirotaro Naotane... Ron STL ... From: Jim Gilbert To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Sent: Monday, January 16, 2006 5:17 PM Subject: Re: [Fwd: Re:
messages.messageBody:
Don't forget Jirotaro Naotane...

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, January 16, 2006 5:17 PM
Subject: Re: [Fwd: Re: [nihontostudy] Tanslation help on a page please]


Both Naotane and Masayoshi made tsuba. Both generations of Naokatsu also. Others did as well, but I can't think of a centralized listing. Most of the survey books (Tsuba Taikan, Tsuba Kanshoki, etc.) show a few examples from that group. There are also examples from famous Shinto smiths.

Jim



Jim et all, that actually brings to mind another thought. Did any of
the other top Tosho of that group produce tsuba, as in Naotane,
Masayoshi or anyone else ??.

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [Fwd: Re: [nihontostudy] Tanslation help on a page please]
messages.msgSnippet: Just for reference, there s an example in the first Compton auction catalogue.  Also one or two by students of his I think. Jim I have Suishinshi Masahide no
messages.messageBody:
Just for reference, there's an example in the first Compton auction catalogue. Also one or two by students of his I think.

Jim





I have Suishinshi Masahide no sono Ichimon and looked through again and
sure enough, there you are. There just seems to be a couple of lines
there about the tsuba, unless buried in the paragraphs that follow. They
are certainly excellent looking tsuba and I may have to try and track
one down when I get to Japan, just for a look at least.

Cheers and thanks again.

Cheers

Richard

messages.subject: Re: [Fwd: Re: [nihontostudy] Tanslation help on a page please]
messages.msgSnippet: Tom, excellent stuff. Thanks very much for that. I had another translation as well form a friend in Japan. He wrote pretty much as you did. ( see link )
messages.messageBody:
Tom, excellent stuff. Thanks very much for that. I had another
translation as well form a friend in Japan. He wrote pretty much as you
did. ( see link )

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/nmb/forum/index.php?action=display&forumid=1&msgid=2644

I have Suishinshi Masahide no sono Ichimon and looked through again and
sure enough, there you are. There just seems to be a couple of lines
there about the tsuba, unless buried in the paragraphs that follow. They
are certainly excellent looking tsuba and I may have to try and track
one down when I get to Japan, just for a look at least.

Cheers and thanks again.

Cheers

Richard






>
>
> Richard-
> In the book Suishinshi Masahide to sono ichimon, there is an
> oshigata of a similar tsuba and a few lines, explaining that he
> indeed did make more but not many. If I understood correctly all iron
> tosho style tsuba appropriately enough. I would love to see one in
> person myself.
> Your page says; This is a Tosho tsuba with kokuin impressed in a
> tsuchime-ji by Suishinshi Masahide. Masahides' great contribution to
> the world of the Japanese sword is evidenced by one well known fact,
> and that is that the Shinshinto era begins with the emergence of this
> very artist. His strength, his energy are evidenced by his having
> answered the demands of the times all the while fostering over 100
> students. He was an extraordinary educator.
> In Token Benkyo Kai first place is Ten (Heaven), second place is Chi
> (Earth) and third place is "Jin" (Man). With this work Masahide makes
> reference to that as well as Buddhistic themes. It is thought with
> this tsuba Masahide is showing us a miniature universe, his kokuin
> reading "Niten" is an abbreviation of Nitenji, a guardian deity who
> is the same as Nichirin (the orb of heaven, the sun).
> In Bunsei Gannen Masahide changed his name to Amahide, one story has
> it that the "Ama" was granted to him by lord Akimoto, suggesting a
> link to the first great swordsmith Amakuni and "lord of swordmakers
> heaven."
> The metal is a bit on the hard side but the color and texture are
> excellent, this is a rare and well known piece.
>
> At least that is what I think it says...
> -t
